user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of test_header:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
test_header (void *cls,
             const char *key,
             size_t key_size,
             const char *value,
             size_t value_size,
             enum MHD_ValueKind kind)
{
  struct test_header_param *const param = (struct test_header_param *) cls;
  struct MHD_Connection *connection = param->connection;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;
  size_t i;

  param->num_headers++;
  i = 0;
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (kind != pos->kind)
      continue;
    if (++i == param->num_headers)
    {
      if (key_size != pos->header_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      if (value_size != pos->value_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      if (0 != key_size)
      {
        mhd_assert (NULL != key);
        mhd_assert (NULL != pos->header);
        if (0 != memcmp (key,
                         pos->header,
                         key_size))
          return MHD_NO;
      }
      if (0 != value_size)
      {
        mhd_assert (NULL != value);
        mhd_assert (NULL != pos->value);
        if (0 != memcmp (value,
                         pos->value,
                         value_size))
          return MHD_NO;
      }
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided function. The code uses only standard C constructs: enums, structs, pointer casts from void*, standard library functions (memcmp), size_t, ordinary control flow (for, if, continue, return), and identifiers/macros that look project-specific (mhd_assert, MHD_YES/MHD_NO) but are not language extensions. There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as GCC/Clang __attribute__ or __extension__, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline assembly (__asm__), labels-as-values, asm goto, nonstandard calling conventions, Microsoft-specific keywords, or other documented compiler-only features. Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation for Rule 1.2 in this code.
